rok commented on pull request #12372:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12372#issuecomment-1034205401


   > us_year seems to better in that regard. (Looking it up - it turns out "epiweek" means something different in the US vs the rest of the world? Oof.)
   
   Well we're looking to mirror [lubridate's epiyear](https://lubridate.tidyverse.org/reference/year.html) for our R implementation, see [ARROW-14824](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14824).
   We could also call it us_epiyear to preventively disambiguate.


--

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description:
We currently support {{epi_week()}} via the {{us_week}} kernel.  Can we support {{epi_year()}} too?

epiyear in lubridate:
https://github.com/tidyverse/lubridate/blob/10731d1876f8cb902f01f8edb2810a09ce5784a4/R/accessors-year.r#L48-L69

I think this might be somewhat similar to MySQL's {{yearweek}}.  It doesn't seem to be implemented universally, e.g. I don't think it's a thing in Postgres

If this isn't something desirable to implement at the C++ level, it's still possible to implement at the R level after a number of other temporal-related functions are implemented.
fields.summary: [C++] Temporal component extraction function for extracting epiyear
